items.label: rem-concentration-lsi
items.title: Concentration of Measure
items.content:
2072: :label: rem-concentration-lsi
2073: 
2074: An additional benefit of the LSI is that it implies strong concentration properties for the QSD. For any Lipschitz function $\phi: (\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N \to \mathbb{R}$ with Lipschitz constant $L_\phi$:
2075: 
2076: $$
2077: \nu_N^{\text{QSD}}\left( \left| \phi - \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{\text{QSD}}}[\phi] \right| \ge t \right) \le 2 \exp\left( -\frac{t^2}{2 C_{\text{LSI}} L_\phi^2} \right)
2078: $$
2079: 
2080: This Gaussian concentration inequality (a consequence of the LSI via Herbst's argument) guarantees that observables under the QSD are tightly concentrated around their mean, with deviations occurring with exponentially small probability. This is a **much stronger statement** than what can be derived from the Foster-Lyapunov analysis alone.

items.label: rem-wfr-analogy
items.title: Formal Analogy and Evidence
items.content:
2171: :label: rem-wfr-analogy
2172: 
2173: Despite the lack of a complete proof, there is strong formal evidence for the conjecture:
2174: 
2175: **Structural analogy:** The adaptive system has the form of a **gradient flow in WFR space**:
2176: - The kinetic evolution is a gradient flow of the free energy in Wasserstein space
2177: - The cloning operator is a gradient flow of relative entropy in Fisher-Rao space
2178: - The WFR metric naturally interpolates between these two geometries
2179: 
2180: **Partial results:**
2181: - For the **backbone system** (without adaptive terms), W₂ contractivity follows from standard theory
2182: - For **simplified selection operators** (e.g., resampling with absolute fitness), FR contractivity is well-established
2183: - The uniform ellipticity (Theorem [](#thm-ueph)) provides the regularity needed for Wasserstein contractivity
2184: 
2185: **What would complete the proof:**
2186: 1. Extend W₂ contraction theory to uniformly elliptic, state-dependent diffusions (possible via Otto calculus)
2187: 2. Prove FR contractivity for competitive, state-dependent selection operators
2188: 3. Apply the Chizat-Peyré-Schmitzer WFR theory to verify the composition
